titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. I began this morning the first of a series of letters which I intend to write to my Son George, upon subjects of serious import. I have had this project in contemplation several Months, and have hitherto done Nothing— My intention is extensive, but not well defined in my own mind. I reflected upon it so much this morning that I wrote but little. I had an arrear of this Journal too to fill up, which I did not accomplish entirely— Walked an hour before dinner round Count Stroganoff’s garden— And as long after dinner, in the botanical garden— Evening visits from Count Jenison-Walworth, Bavarian Secretary of legation, and Baron Gremp de Freudenstein Counsellor of the Legations of the king of Wurtemberg. I was not at home— I read Sections 40 and 41. of Robinson’s character of Christ, and two Sermons in the British Preacher— On hearing the word of God, and on the folly of mocking at Sin.— I also read a Tale by Madame de Montolieu; from the German of Musens; called Melechsala, or the language of flowers.

2. Morning visits from Mr Harris with Mr Swiachkoff, who is going out in the Dorothea to Philadelphia, to be Mr. Daschkoff’s Secretary of Legation— And in the same vessel Mr. Kosloff, the Consul-General, Mr Swienin, adjoint Consul, and Mr Eliesen, private Secretary to Mr: Daschkoff, intend also to embark.— Mr Moses and Mr Fisher were here at the same time, and Mr Plummer with Mr Ashton. Mr. Moses intends going in two or three days for England.— He asked me to procure for him a Courier’s Passport; but having no despatches to send, I could not comply with his request— As there are great advantages of convenience in travelling with Courier’s Passes, all the Americans who go away by land are extremely desirous of obtaining them— But considering that it would be an abuse to apply for this special Pass, with out having any despatches to send, and merely for the private accommodation of individuals, I have always refused it unless when I had occasion for a messenger, and was therefore obliged to deny Mr Moses.— Mr Ashton is going immediately to Riga— I found from Mr Plummer that by a mistake my letters and despatches which I sent for him on Saturday were delivered not to him,
but to Mr Fisher, who afterwards wrote me a note, saying that he had sent them down to Cronstadt— Captain Lovett is not yet gone.— Mrs Adams dined below; the first time since her Confinement— After dinner I paid a visit at Mr Laval’s— I found Count Maistre and the Chevalier Brancia there; and Mr Labensky—but a company smaller than usual— Madame de Laval was absent—went yesterday to Pavlofsky, and had not returned— She came home while I was there— I asked Mr Laval some questions about the two institutions of Cadets— One of them is to educate Officers for the army, and the other, Officers for the Navy— The army Cadets are under the direction and management of the Grand Duke Constantine— They are taught the manual exercise in great perfection, and little or nothing else— The Marine Cadets are under the inspection of Captain Krusenstern and Mr Laval— Of the Captain for the practical part, and of Mr Laval, for the part of Instruction— They enter from nine to eleven years of age, and remain there six years, after which they are obliged to serve as marine Officers, with the appointment of Midshipmen— The three last years of their attendance at the school, they are bas-officiers, and gardes-marines, and when the sea is open and free to them, are sent out on board frigates to cruize in the Baltic to learn the practice of Navigation— This part of their duty now is confined to the Navigation, between this City and Cronstadt.— They are taught the mathematics with great assiduity, and many of them make great and surprizing proficiency in them. They are also taught the French, and English languages, and some of them German— But the greatest attention is paid to the French— There are thirteen teachers of that language alone— But then there are seven hundred pupils, belonging to the Institution— Their numbers occasion the greatest inconvenience— And another heavy misfortune is the depretiation of the paper money— The funds remain the same as they were in the time of the Empress Catherine; while the money has depretiated to the rate of four for one— The masters have salaries of two hundred roubles a year, when they ought to have two thousand— Good Masters therefore are not to be had— Notwithstanding which this is the best naval school in the Country— Mr Laval promised me that he would some day accompany me, and shew me the buildings and arrangements of the Institution— While I was there a heavy thunder-shower came up— I returned home in the midst of it— After it was over Mr Gray, Mr Fisher and Mr Jones came out from the City— Jones and Fisher pass’d the rest of the Evening with us untill Midnight— Mr Gray stayed to lodge here— Jones is soon going away, and asked me for a Courier’s Pass, or a letter to J. S. Smith— I promised him the letter; and the pass, if at the time of his departure I should have occasion to send despatches.

3. The french Ambassador sent me the Moniteur from the 11th: to the 16th: of August containing the Memoir with the name of the Duke of Cadore, in a translation from the London Courier of 30. July, and also a number of paragraphs extracted from several other English newspapers, concerning it— The Moniteur declares it an English forgery— Count Romanzoff afterwards sent me a packet from Mr Russell at Paris, brought by a Courier— Mr Russell encloses to me the Moniteur’s of 13 and 14. August containing the Memoir; and some paragraphs about it, and the New-York Commercial Advertiser of 22. June, also containing it, and announcing it as extracted from the Boston Patriot. Mr Russell’s letter to me expresses great doubts whether it was genuine or not.— In Mr Russell’s letters were enclosed for Mr Harris, Mr Patterson and the Brothers Cramer— I went into the City after dinner, and delivered to Mr Harris his letter and that for Mr Patterson who is gone to Archangel— I left that for the brothers Cramer at Mr S. Cramer’s house— Called at Mr Fisher’s and then at Mr Bezerra’s— He and his lady had just returned from a visit to our house, but had not been received— On returning home I found cards from Mr: & Madm: Rayneval. The stormy, cold, and rainy autumnal weather has already set in— It began the last week in August— It is already and constantly so cold that I find it very difficult to write in my Cabinet without a fire.

4. I sent home the papers which the French Ambassador had lent me yesterday, with enquiries whether he could see me this day and at what hour? He sent me word he should be at home the whole day, and would receive me when I pleased— I called upon him about one in the afternoon, and thanked him for the loan of the papers— I had then some Conversation with him upon general subjects— His papers came by a Russian Courier to Count Romanzoff—his own Courier, whom he has for some time expected has not yet arrived— He complained that his Courier’s were all dispatched to him late. I asked him if he was still as confident of Peace as the last week— He said yes—at least there could be no War now—it was too late— He had heard indeed that the Emperor Napoleon had made a promotion upon his birth day, 15. August of fifty brigadier-generals, and several Generals of division at once; which could hardly be true— There had very probably been however a promotion, and it might be unusually numerous; for there had been none, since the last Campaign against Austria— It was said too that the Emperor Napoleon had had a conversation with the Russian Ambassador, Prince Kurakin— That was very probable; but as the substance of it had been reported to this Government by Prince Kurakin; and as neither the Emperor nor Count Romanzoff, had told the substance of it to any body, it was evident there could have been nothing in it of an
unfavourable nature; for if there had been they certainly would have spoken of it— The Ambassador’s reasoning must go upon the principle that by any thing of an unfavourable nature, he means express War— He said that when the Russian Courier came from Paris the Emperor Napoleon was going to Compiéque, and perhaps to Holland; which would further increase the suspicions and alarms here. But he would be returned so soon after his departure that they would not have time to be alarmed long— He had heard too that the Generals had been appointed here; but this was merely a rumour— On the whole I saw that the General himself was not perfectly sure how affairs actually stood, and that although he really believes the Peace will continue, he is not altogether without his doubts— I asked him to forward by his next Courier a letter for Mr Russell at Paris, which he promised, requesting me to have it ready and sent it to him by to-morrow Evening— I returned home and began the letter, but was obliged to go into the City to dine with Mr Fisher at 5. O’Clock— I therefore left the letter unfinished— Mr Fisher had a Company of about twenty persons; mostly Americans; but among them were Mr Kosloff the Consul-General, and Mr Swienin the adjoint Consul, who are going out to Philadelphia in the Dorothea— Mr Swiechkoff, and Mr Eliesen were to have been there; but were prevented by the preparations for their departure. The vessel is to be ready to go to-morrow four or five days sooner than they had expected— In the Evening I stop’d to see Mr Pitt, the Chaplain of the English Church, but he was not at home— I called on Mr Harris, with whom I found Commodore Bainbridge— I walked home— And was up untill two in the morning finishing my letter to Mr Russell— Mr Smith came into my Cabinet about one, and asked me to look at the Comet, which I did— It was below the tail of the Great Bear, and not so large as the Comet of 1807— The night was clear and Cold.

5. I wrote a shorter letter than usual to the Secretary of State, to avoid missing the opportunity of writing by the Dorothea— I sent also to the French Ambassador my letter to Mr Russell.— I went into the City, called on Mr Pitt, and asked him to baptize my new-born daughter, next Monday, which he promised, and to be ready at any hour of which I should inform him by a note.— I went and looked over a house to be let, belonging to a Count Bulgarin, who was there and shewed me over it.— It is on the Fontanka near the Peterhoff gate; and consequently too remote from the centre of the City— He will not lease it for less than a year from the first of September old Style, and asks 4000 Rubles for it unfurnished, or 6000. furnished, without fire-wood— I promised to send him an answer to-morrow— Called and left a note for Madame Bezerra, from Mrs Adams, requesting her to stand as God-mother at the Christening of our daughter— I walked home— In the Evening Mr and Madame Bezerra came out to see us— She accepts to stand as God-mother, though a Roman Catholic.— Mr Harris also paid me an Evening visit.

6. My Thermometer this morning in my bed-room stood at 7. degrees of Reaumur 48 of Fahrenheit— It had been three or four days at 8. or 50. the cold was so chilling that I could no longer hold my pen to write, and I had a fire made in my stove—the weather moderated in the course of the day, and at Night my room was at 15 and 65 degrees—the just medium of temperature for writing, in the day-time. Mr: Smith of Boston and Mr Swan came out on a visit— Broke their Carriage axle-tree as they came into the yard, and returned in mine. I wrote a Note to Dr: Pitt, fixing four O’Clock in the afternoon next Monday for the Christening— Visited Mr: and Mrs: Bentzon, and invited them to attend it, and to dine with us— Also Mr Labouchere but he was engaged— Dined at General Watzdorff’s. Count Bussche and Baron Arnim, a Swedish Gentleman who lives with Mr: Schenbom, and Mr Gray, were all the Company— Called on Mr Harris and invited him to stand as Sponsor at the Baptism, which he accepted— Walked home and found Mr. Fisher and Mr Jones at my house— Mr: Plummer afterwards came in with Mr Loring Austin, who brought me a letter from Governor Gerry— The Evening was fine and the Comet very conspicuous.

7. Mr Montreal called on me this morning immediately after breakfast and next to him Dr Griffith— From the time they left me, all the remainder of the day was absorbed in avocations of petty domestic concerns which prevent me from writing, much to my own annoyance— I went into the City with Catherine, merely to procure an Ewer and Bason for the ceremony on Monday.— We called to see Mrs Bentzon but she was not at her lodgings— From Regnaud the hatter’s in the Nefsky Perspective I walked home. Immediately after dinner I heard of a house in the City, and went to look over it. In many respects I find it suitable, though not equal to that we left— Mrs Adams is to look over it on Tuesday next. I then went to Mr Krehmer’s in the Country, after calling at Mr Harris’s for my letters and papers, but there was nobody at home who could give them to me— I asked Mr: and Mrs Krehmer and their daughter, and Miss Fock who was there to dine with us on Monday, and Mrs Krehmer to stand as second Godmother to the child— She accepted, and they will come— I came home about ten in the Evening. Mr Jones visited me this morning— At night there was a great fête and illumination at Count
Strogonoff’s Gardens, and a great Maskerade at Mr P. Severin’s, which Mr: Smith, Jones and Fisher attended.— The night fine, and the Comet brilliant.

8. After finishing a letter, begun three or four days ago, I continued that to my Son George, which I intend to be the first of a series— But as I advance, I find the want of a plan arranged in my own mind— I am already so much dissatisfied with what I have written, find my ideas so undigested and confused, feel so much my own ignorance upon the subjects concerning which I mean to instruct him, and am so remote from the helps to which I might recur for assistance, that I am afraid I have in this instance as in numberless others undertaken more than I can execute— I have not yet however abandoned it entirely— Dined at Mr Laval’s with a Company of twenty-five persons— Count Romanzoff, the French Ambassador, and most of the other foreign Ministers were there— Returned home immediately after dinner— Found Mr: Blodget and Mr Craig at my house— They pass’d the Evening with us untill about ten— I read two Sections of Robinson’s character of Christ, 42. and 43. And the Sermons 5. and 6. in the first volume of the English preacher—on the unchangeable difference between Good and Evil; and on Self-love—

9. Finished the first of my letters to George, and took the walk round, and over the four Bridges— Four O’Clock P.M. was fixed for the Christening of my infant daughter— The Company invited, assembled at that hour— The Revd: London King Pitt, Chaplain to the English factory Church, performed the Ceremony— Levett Harris Esqr. Consul of the United States, in this City was the Godfather, and Madam Bezerra the Lady of the Portugueze Minister, and Mrs: Anette Krehmer were the God mothers— The witnesses present were, the Chevalier Bezerra, General Watzdorf and Count Bussche, Portuguese, Saxon and Westphalian Ministers, the Chevalier Navarro, Mr: and Mrs Bentzon, Mr. Krehmer and his daughter Sally, Commodore Bainbridge, and Messrs: Blodget, Fisher, Gray, Harris junr: and Jones—together with our own family. The child was baptized by the name of Louisa-Catherine, being that of her mother.— The Ceremony took about a quarter of an hour, and immediately after it was over we sat down to dinner— Great part of the Company spent the Evening with us, and we had Cards— I played Whist with Mr Bezerra, Mr Jones and Mr Gray.— My eldest Son, and my daughter have been baptized according to the rites of the Church of England— My Sons John and Charles were baptized at Boston, by my worthy friend Emerson now deceased— I think the ceremony of baptism as performed in our Congregational Churches, much more proper and rational than that of the English Church— I have both in this instance and in that of my Son George recurred to the ceremony in this form, only because I thought the rite itself essential, and because the forms of the English Church, are the most like to those which I have considered as the best, and to which I myself was born, that I could have access to— The motives for my preference of our own form of baptism are 1— Because it is done in Church, a place devoted to Divine worship, and in the presence of the Congregation— It is therefore more solemn and more public than a private baptism can be; both of which are characters peculiarly well suited to this act. 2. Because it is much more simple, performed only with a previous and a succeeding prayer of the Clergyman, without any entanglement of creeds and controversial doctrines. 3. Because the father of the Child is the only Sponsor, and solemnly undertakes, what it is his duty to perform; that is to educate the Child to virtuous and Christian Principles.— While the Sponsors of an English Christening, are often Strangers, who are never likely to have any controul over the child, and therefore rashly enter into solemn engagements, the performance of which will never depend upon themselves.— But the rite itself, the solemn dedication of the child to God, I prize so highly, that I think it ought never to be deferred beyond a time of urgent necessity.

10. Employed the morning in writing to my mother— Mrs Adams went into the City, and looked over the house which I had seen last Saturday, and with which she is very much pleased— I dined at the French Ambassador’s, with a Company of about fifty-five persons, a Great Diplomatic dinner, in honour of the Emperor Alexander’s name-day, which is to-morrow— I arrived rather late: and as the Company all went away immediately after dinner the party was unusually short. I sat between the Minister of the Interior Kosadawleff, and General Watzdorf, but we had no interesting Conversation. Mr Kosodawleff values himself so much upon the principle that the Government should intermeddle as little as possible with the affairs of individuals, that one would imagine he had no other— I returned immediately home after dinner— Found Mr Jones at my house; but he soon went away.

11. Having attended the Ceremony, at the Monastery of St: Alexander Newsky, the last year, I omitted it this time— I wrote Notes to Count Romanzoff requesting a Courier’s Passport for Mr Gray, who is going to Paris, and to Dr: Pitt requesting a duplicate Certificate of the baptism of my Daughter— I took the Notes into the City and left them at their destinations— Mrs: Adams and
Charles went into the City, with me, and we looked again over the house at the Corner of the little Officers Street— The owner declines letting it for a shorter term than three years;—I offered to take it upon his own terms for one year, and he promised to send me his answer to-morrow morning— I called at Mr Harris’s house for my letters and papers, but there was nobody at home— I desired they might be sent out to me, which they were before dinner— There were from the Bridge to the lower Admiralty a string of frigates and yachts dressed out in Colours, in honour of the day— I called at Demuth’s Hotel to pay a visit to Mr Parker, but he was not at his lodgings— I walked home, and passed through the Summer-Gardens which I found wholly deserted— After dinner I took another walk— Mr. Smith of Boston was here, for letters to go by the Cygnet— Mr: and Madam Bezerra were also here in the Evening.— The City was illuminated.

12. The son of the owner of the house which we saw yesterday came this morning, and we agreed upon the terms on which I am to take the house— I am to give five thousand Rubles for it for one year, to commence from to-morrow, with the very few Articles of furniture now in it— In which are to be included two hundred Sagenes of wood for the year— For so much I shall have the right to call; but if I do not want the whole I am still to pay for so much— I am to pay half a year in advance on entering the house, and to be responsible for fire if occasioned by the fault of any person in my family— A Lease is to be drawn, and I paid one hundred Rubles, as earnest money, and in account— Some of these Conditions are hard, but I had no prospect of doing so well by waiting longer— Dined at Count Romanzoff’s with a diplomatic Company of about sixty persons— The Chevalier de Bray was there; just returned from his Journey— And Baron Munk, who has come to settle in Russia— I sat next to General Pardo at table— He is writing a dissertation upon the pronunciation of the Greek language— After dinner I called and took my papers at Mr Harris’s— Evening visit from Mr Labouchere— He intends going for Amsterdam on Saturday— The cold weather is setting in again, and I can scarcely write without a fire.

13. Mr Jones and Mr Gray were desirous of having the French Ambassador’s visa upon my Passports which they are to take with them to France— I asked him yesterday if I could call and see him this morning, and at what hour— He asked me to come and dine with him. I went accordingly at 5. The Chevalier de Bray and Count Jenison were there— M. and Madame Rayneval, and Mr Lesseps— And the Ambassadors family excepting St: Genest— While at dinner we had such a shower of hail that after it the ground looked as if covered with Snow— The Ambassador took the two Passports, and said he would send them to me to-morrow— He said he would also write to Mentz—to inform the commanding Officer there that these Gentlemen were coming; that they might immediately proceed to Paris, without waiting. After dinner Rayneval played on the Piano, and sung— I returned home early— Mr: Jones and Mr Gray dined at our house; and we had Evening visits from the Chevalier de Bray and Count Jenison, from Mrs Bentzon, and from Mr Fisher and Mr Connell— I had taken a long morning walk during which Mr: Harris had paid me a visit with Mr Anderson, the Consul appointed from the United States to reside at Gothenburg, and who has just arrived from Archangel— Mr Woodward also called; but I saw none of them. Our Evening Company stayed untill near Midnight.

14. I have hitherto had a fire in my Cabinet and Bed-room, which is the same, only one day last week; but the weather is becoming so steadily cold that I shall henceforth be obliged to have it constantly— This day it raised the thermometer in my Room only to 11.— The morning was cold, the day showery and at Night it cleared off leaving the external thermometer at 2— The Comet is brilliant, increasing in size, and moving westward— I employed the day, chiefly in writing to my father— Received from Count Romanzoff the Courier’s Passport for Mr Gray. And several Packets for the Russian Minister at Berlin, and the Ambassador at Paris— Mr Montreal was here this morning, and after him Mr Woodward— Mr Fisher came in the Evening, and I gave him my despatches and letters for America, to take with him tomorrow to Cronstadt.

15. I found it this morning so cold when I rose that I could not write in my chamber, and the weather being fine, I walked into the City, and took a tour in the Summer Garden before breakfast. After dinner I walked again to the Botanic Garden and round it— The remainder of the day, I was employed without interruption, writing and reading according to my wish— But the magnitude of the subject, which I have undertaken to treat in the letters to my Son George, already oppresses me— I pray that I may not be discouraged; but that meditation, may enlighten my ignorance, enlarge my views, and disentangle the Confusion of my ideas— In writing this day my second letter, I consulted Cicero de Natura Deorum—Plato’s second Alcibiades, on prayer—And Ovid’s Metamorphoses— I wanted Plato’s Timaeus, but have not the Book— In the Evening I read the concluding Sections 44 and 45. of Robinson’s character of Christ—and Sermons 7. and 8 in the first volume of the English Preacher.

16. Confined to the house all day by the badness of the weather— Mr Plummer and a young Mr Norman were here in the morning— Mr Jones and Mr Fisher dined with us— We had Evening visits from Dr: Griffith and Mr Craig, and from Mr Harris and Mr Anderson, the Gentleman appointed as Consul at Gothenburg, and who arrived a few days since from Archangel— I did nothing this day, but finish my letter, begun yesterday, to my Son George.

17. Mr Jones and Mr Gray breakfasted with us, and immediately afterwards took leave and departed upon their Journey to Paris. Mr Fisher and Captain Boit were here in the Evening— I walked before and after dinner, and wrote a short letter to America. I read the Review of Clarke’s Travels in Russia, in the Edinburg Review— It is the bitterest libel upon Russia that I have ever yet met with— I had time for nothing else.— It is the Empress’s Name-day, and the City was illuminated.

18. Morning visit from Mr: Montreal— The rest of the day I had no interruption, but I lost it— Three O’Clock in the afternoon came upon me without my knowing how the morning had past— It is thus that my life slips away— I heard Charles read about half an hour— He comes to me of his own accord, but it is for his apple or pear, or sugar plums, without which I cannot prevail upon him to read— He is not under my management yet, and I do not therefore exercise the controul which would bring him to it. He reads besides this, almost every day to Godfrey, and has certainly made some progress— But it is very slow— I comfort myself that he is learning practically to speak both French and German, so that we are losing no time with him— In him as in my other children I perceive that the great difficulty of learning, is that of fixing attention—the sight of a boat, a noise in any other part of the house, a fly lighting upon the table, every thing that can catch his eye or his ear diverts him from his book— I find to this day the same thing in myself, and it is the greatest, perhaps the only Cause which has bound the voyage of my life in shallows— Genius, is nothing but the power of applying the mind to its object— I walked nearly two hours before dinner, and one after—round Count Strogonoff’s Garden, and to the Wyburg Bridge.— In the Evening I read in the Edinburg review; but my eyes have almost deserted me— I passed the greatest part of it in the Nursery—that is in my wife’s chamber.

19. I received this morning a Note from Mr Craig, informing me that he had heard there was to be a Ball this Evening at the French Ambassadors, and requesting me, to present him to the Ambassador, and to allow him to accompany me there— I answered him that I regretted I could not present any American at the French Ambassadors, unless he had been previously presented at Court— I returned the visit of the Chevalier de Bray, where I found Mr St: Genest, and Mr Harris— M: de Bray gave some particulars of the mode of Courtly living at Paris, which made me doubly rejoyce at having no Call there— St: Genest complained of the manner in which the diplomatic establishment in France is organized and said that if he, or Rayneval were to go to Paris they could not be presented at Court; because they were not Auditeur’s—though Prevost their junior, having that title would be— They were refused it, and were told it was because they were above it— Besides which, to obtain it proof must be given of having an income of six thousand livres a year— I called on Mr: Harris, and had some conversation with him concerning this curious application to me, of Mr Craig— I told him that I had adopted as rules which experience had rendered necessary 1— To present no Gentleman at Court, without first obtaining an express permission, from Count Romanzoff— 2. To present in person, no one, to Count Romanzoff, to the foreign Ministers or to any body, except at Court. 3. To solicit no letters for any one, to persons in other Countries— The Ambition of young Americans to crowd themselves upon European Courts, and into the Company of Nobility, is a very ridiculous and not very proud feature of their character— There is nothing in my estimate of things meaner than Courting Society where if admitted, it is only to be despised— Yet such is this vicious Appetite for great acquaintance, and so little delicacy has it that an American Minister abroad can preserve himself from sharing in the scorn which it excites, only by adopting some such general rules as these— I gave Mr Harris also some letters, to send down to Cronstadt, and one from a Sailor, claiming assistance— Mr Harris told me of letters from America, containing certain political speculations— I walked partly home— In the Evening I attended the Ball at the Ambassadors; and stayed about two hours— There were about a hundred persons— I returned home about eleven O’Clock.

20. Messrs: Anderson, Austin, Boit, Connell, Craig, Fisher, Griffith, Harris and his nephew, Hollins, Montreal, Parker, Roberts and Saltus dined with us— I had requested Mr Fisher last Monday, to invite Mr Calhoun, and Commodore Bainbridge, but they did not come, and I was informed by Mr Harris that it was because they were displeased with the mode of the invitation— I desired Mr Harris
to give my Compliments to them, and tell them that if I invited them again to my house it should be by Card.— Mr: Saltus informed me that a Mr Kenyon an American who was here last Winter had shot himself at Riga— Mr: and Mrs Bentzon were here in the Evening.

21. Madame Colombi, and her Sister Frederica came to see our Ladies this morning and found us at Breakfast— I went into the City, and called upon Mr Anderson at Walbesky’s to enquire whether any body was going with him to Sweden— He mentioned Mr Connell— I applied to Count Romanzoff for a Courier’s Passport for him, and left it at the Count’s Hotel— I left Cards at the lodgings of Commodore Bainbridge and Mr Colhoun, and then called on Mr Harris, where I found my newspapers and a couple of letters— Mr Harris had written me a note mentioning that he had seen Commodore Bainbridge this morning, who had assured him that his not having come yesterday to dinner, was altogether owing to Mr Fisher’s having delivered the invitation in such doubtful terms, that they knew not whether they were really invited or not.— I received also a letter of 21. June from my Mother—Containing news of the ill-health of my brother, and of Mrs Cranch, which give me great concern— I visited Madame Bezerra, the Chevalier not being at home— Desired her to mention that I was dispatching a Gentleman with a Courier’s Pass to Gothenburg, and request Mr Bezerra to send his letters if he should have any to me by Monday Evening— I walked partly home, and again after dinner on the river’s Banks— Evening idle.

22. I walked this morning an hour and a half before breakfast, and after dinner two turns on the Mall, from our door to the Karpoffka—which takes me three quarters of an hour— From breakfast untill dinner, I was writing to George— I found the need of reading Plato’s Phaedo, which I fortunately have in the French Translation and read in Part— In the Education of my Children, the most important Object appears to me to lay for them a firm and steady foundation of Morals— Upon that basis every thing else must be built. This is my principal motive for beginning now to write letters to George, which he certainly will not understand— But the more I write, the more I find the subject as much beyond my own capacity as his— In the Evening I read Robinson’s character of the Virgin Mary, and two Sermons in the English Preacher— One by Atterbury on the Duty of Thanksgiving; and one, on the Christian rule of equity— It is better discussed in a number of the Rambler.— Commodore Bainbridge and Mr Colhoun paid me a visit this morning, and apologized for not having come to dinner on Friday— Mr Fisher forgot my request to him to invite them, for three days, and then did not give it properly.— The explanation is satisfactory.

23. I finished the letter yesterday begun, but it employed me all the morning, and untill four O’Clock— In the Evening I began a letter to my brother— Before dinner I walked round Count Strogonoff’s Garden; and in the Evening, twice up and down the Mall, from my door to the Karpoffka— Mr: and Madame Bezerra paid us a short visit— Mr Bezerra left a Packet for Gothenburg; to be taken by Mr: Anderson.— Mrs Adams rode this day to the City, and for the first time took out her infant daughter— Catherine went with Charles and Martha to see Mrs Colombi, but did not find her at home— Mrs A. in the Evening was ill with a head-ache.

24. Mr: Plummer paid me a visit this morning with Mr Haven, a young American, whom I think I have seen before— I walked the tour round the Bridges, before dinner, and to the French Ambassador’s in the Evening, but he was not at home— I took one turn upon the Mall— Mr Blodget and Mr Fisher spent a couple of hours with us in the Evening.— The Comet increases in brightness and in size— It is incomparably larger than that of 1807. and according to a publication this day by the Academy of Sciences, the largest that has been seen for more than a Century— I finished reading the Phaedo this morning before I rose from bed— The argument for the immortality of the Soul is, as Count Maistre in his preface says un peu foible; but there are in the dialogue many excellent passages.— The position that every thing proceeds from its contrary, and therefore life must come from death is sophistical— That about equal and unequal numbers, is unintelligible jargon— But I found in this work the original from which Dryden took the first Strophe of his Ode to St: Cecilia, where the world is said to have Sprung from Harmony— Campbell, I think in his philosophy of rhetoric says it is nonsense— But he does not appear to be aware that it is the nonsense of Plato.

25. I began this morning to read the Bibliothéque des Philosophes, and read, about two hours before I rose from bed— There is nearly a volume of introductions— I read the Preliminary Discourse of the Editor (anonymous) and a Discourse upon Plato by the Abbé de Fleury— I undertake this reading with a reference to my letters to George— Mr Montreal called upon me immediately
after breakfast, and detained me untill twelve O’Clock— I then went and called upon the French Ambassador but he was gone out— I intended to have gone into the City but it was too late. I walked in the Botanical Garden with Charles— Dined with Mr Fisher, it being his birth-day— He had about fifteen other Americans of the Company. I stop’d at Mr Harris’s as I came home for my letters and papers; but he was not at home— I could neither write nor read in the Evening.

26. I called again at eleven O’Clock this morning upon Count Lauriston, and this time found him at home— He had some musicians with him, and violins and a base-viol, and music Stands, so that he was preparing for a family Concert— I invited him and all his family to dine with us next Monday— They agreed to come— I asked permission to send a letter to Mr Russell by his next Courier— He said he should send one on Sunday— He spoke of the Emperor Napoleon’s being at Compiegne, where he said it was probable he would stay longer than had been expected— That he would perhaps go to Holland, but probably not to Hamburg— He mentioned paragraphs in the English papers saying that he was trying to keep Count Romanzoff in Office here, but that he would certainly be turned out— He also mentioned the English Sloop of War, and the Store-ships at Revel— I asked him if they were gone— He said they were gone out of the harbour; but were still anchored below— And the Emperor Alexander had told him his naval force had not a superiority adequate to drive them from thence— He asked me if I had any late Accounts from the United States— I told him, none— That scarcely any American vessels had arrived here within the last Month. And that his countrymen I believed were in part the cause of it— How so?— A number of privateers under french Colours had taken stand at the passage of the Sound, which was now not blockaded by the English; one of those privateers had taken to my knowledge two American vessels coming here, and those which were going from here were considered as in great danger of being taken by them also— He said it was the difficulty of discriminating between our vessels, and the English which made ours liable to capture— And the English themselves boasted of the use they made of our flag— He had but a few days ago, seen a paragraph stating that Admiral Saumarez had permitted two hundred vessels to come under American Colours from Gothenburg into the Baltic— I told him undoubtedly the English favoured this deception as much as they could, for the sake of exposing our vessels to be taken for theirs and exposed to the same capture— It was their interest to prevent the discrimination, but it was the interest of France, as well as ours to make it. I then repeated to him the means by which it is so easy to make the discrimination, wherever there is an American Minister or Consul— He asked me if I would furnish me with a list of those which had sailed from here this Season, and which I considered as unquestionably American— That he would transmit it to Paris; and then if any of them should be taken they might be more speedily liberated. I promised to furnish him such a list, and he said I had better send another copy of the same list to Mr Russell— I mentioned to him that among the American Vessels, arrived at Cronstadt, there were three with false papers, which we had detected, and which had been seized and would be confiscated— But said he—I do not mean to speak of it by way of complaint— I do not wish to trouble any body— But between us two there must be many more than three vessels under American Colours, which have come with false papers, or which at least have come from England— Well, between us two said I, and speaking with the same confidence as you express, there are many American vessels, which I believe came from England; but they all came in Ballast— Of loaded vessels, I assure you: not that there have been none; but to my full perswasion scarcely any— As to vessels coming in Ballast, the Government here hardly ask any questions—they come to export Russian produce and manufactures; which is an object of so much importance here, that they do not trouble themselves about the flag.— I understood him to say that he had seen a list of fifty-five American vessels that had arrived with Cargoes, and of thirty-three, in Ballast— He also said here had been within a few days a seizure of one or more loaded vessels which came under the Pappenburg flag— I have no doubt that in asking me for the list, besides the motive which he avowed to me he had that of collecting information upon the subject, according to instructions lately received— I know that Mr Lesseps has received such instructions— Mr: Longuerue walked with me, as far as my door.— Soon after returning home I went out again to see the annual exhibition at the Academy of Arts— It is much inferior to that of the last year— The paintings are all very bad— There was a subject of National History the Czar John Wasilievitz giving a poor soldier to drink from a helmet, treated by several of the Students at the Academy of what they call the 4th: age, or Class— The four prize pieces in painting, and the four in basso-relievo were exhibited— There were a few historical and fancy pieces exposed by persons to obtain the rank of Academician; and a few Portraits— One of the best pictures there was a repose of Suworow; by Mr Swienin the Gentleman who is gone to America, as adjoint Consul, and with whom I dined at Mr Fisher’s— A visit to this place is however always interesting and agreeable, on account of
of the models from Antique Statues, which are always exhibited— They are numerous, and many of them well executed— But the Print-shop, and particularly the very bad prints exposed for sale in one of the halls seems an incongruity— The indifferent Pictures hanging in the Halls is another— I observed again the full-length Portrait of the Emperor Paul, which I had noticed last year— It is well painted—but the air of dignity attempted to be given him, with his countenance and person, is as incongruous as his purple tunic, and Imperial Crown and Robe, with an enormous pair of Jack-Boots, armed with Spurs.— I met Baron Schladen, Mr Jouffroy, and Mr B. Cramer at the Academy. The Baron has a leave of absence for six months, on Account of his health, and told me he should go in about three weeks— I went from the Academy to Count St: Julien’s, but he was not at home— I called on Mr Harris, and found Mr Ecky with him— He arrived last Evening with Mr Patterson from Archangel— He shewed me a letter from Mr Dimond at Gothenburg mentioning that Mr Colvin had published a piece in America, claiming to be the author of the letters to Genl: Armstrong and Genl: Turreau, which Mr R. Smith in his pamphlet had published as his own— I requested Mr Harris to have a list of vessels made out, which I had promised to the French Ambassador, and told him for what purpose— He promised to have it done immediately— I then called upon the Chevalier de Bray, and invited him and Count Jenison to dine with us on Monday, which they promised—the Chevalier told me that there was a verbal invitation to the Corps Diplomatique, to attend at the Consecration of the new Church of our Lady of Kazan, to-morrow morning at ten O’Clock— On returning home I found that one of the Aids of the Master of Ceremonies had been to give us the same Notice— I sent word of it to Mr Harris, and walked home— I asked the Chevalier de Bray whether he knew what were the particulars of the Conversation held on the 15th: of August between the 567, and Prince Kurakin— He said the Emperor began by speaking of the Accounts from the Russian army, and told the Prince, that although General Kutuzoff had claimed the Victory at the late affair of Rustshuk it was evident by the result that he was not entitled to it, since he had been since obliged to abandon Rustshuk itself, to repass the Danube, and to give up every thing that the Russians had gained in the last Campaign. That the reason why he, Napoleon had claimed the victory at the Battle of Essling was because he had maintained his position upon the Island, and the head of the Bridge on the opposite shore, so that he was enabled to rebuild his Bridge and pass again, as soon as he was in force— That he could not help being surprized and somewhat uneasy, at seeing the Emperor of Russia, of whose Judgment and honour he had the highest sense, weaken so excessively his army where he was actually at War, to increase his armaments in Poland where there was no danger of his being attacked— That with regard to the Duchy of Oldenburg, that was included in the Confederation of the Rhine— That the Duke had not fulfilled the Obligations resting upon him in that capacity— That he Napoleon might therefore have put him to the Ban of the Empire, and considered it as an affair of internal concern, in which no foreign power had a right to interfere— But out of regard and consideration for the Emperor of Russia he had offered, and was still ready to give ample indemnity to the Duke of Oldenburg, and he asked Prince Kurakin if he had powers to conclude a Convention upon the subject—the Prince said he had not, upon which the Emperor said that he was ready to make the arrangement whenever it should please the Emperor of Russia. But if he had not the highest Confidence in that Prince’s Justice and honour he should have been suspicious that he meant to attack him, and in such a War he did not know upon what ally Russia could depend. This discourse naturally struck the Russian Ambassador with surprize, and alarm; but the Duke of Bassano immediately afterwards gave the Ambassador the strongest assurances that it was not intended to indicate any hostile intentions; the substance of it was again repeated in a Circular despatch from him, which has been sent to the French Ministers at all the Courts where the Russian protestation of last Spring had been sent.— I employed the whole Evening in writing to anticipate the loss of to-morrow, which I saw would be unavoidable.

27. Went with Mr: Smith in full dress, and attended at the Consecration of the new Church, of the Mother of God of Kazan. We were there punctually at ten O’Clock, and found it difficult to get in, owing to the immense Crowd— It was about eleven when the Emperor, and Imperial family came in, the Emperor having to his constant custom upon all Holidays begun the day by a Parade of the troops. From that time untill half-past two the Ceremonies were performing, so that we stood between four hours and a half and five hours— The stone floor of the Church too was somewhat cold and uncomfortable— There was a large Carpet for the Emperor and imperial family to stand upon, and a narrow Stair-carpet for the Priests to pass over; upon which we had frequent and earnest notices not to encroach.— We were placed, after sundry removals to and fro by Count Romanzoff, and the Grand Master of Ceremonies Narishkin, at a stand opposite the place where the Emperor stood—and in full view of him— The services were performed by the Metropolitan Ambrose, and the other dignitaries of the Church who usually perform with him— The Ceremonies were excessively long, and in very few particulars
sufficiently significant to be understood by me. At one stage of it the Priests, followed by the Emperor and Imperial family, went in procession out of the Church, and marched round it, carrying the holy relics, and the sacred, miraculous image of the Virgin to whom the Church is dedicated— At another the four ends of the Church at the East one of which hung a full length image of the Virgin, and the three others of which are the doors, were anointed with Oil, by a small brush at the end of a long pole—the kneeling was twice repeated, and once continued longer than usual— The Priests were in their customary garments, and the Metropolitan’s Mitre was studded with costly precious stones— The quire of singers performed their parts as usual— General Pardo and the Chevalier de Bray soon got weary after the Ceremony commenced— Old Count Strogonoff stayed untill the last half hour but was then obliged to retire— He had received us at first and said to us Je suis charmé de vous recevoir chèz moi—car c’est encore chèz moi— That is the Church has been built under his superintendence, as President of the Academy of Arts— It is one of the most magnificent Churches that I ever saw.— It has been about eleven years building, having been begun during the reign of the late Emperor Paul— After returning home I took a short walk; but in the Evening, though a little urged for time was too much fatigued either for writing or reading.— Mr: and Madame Bezerra paid us an evening visit.

28. Mr Montreal paid me a visit this morning.— I wrote a letter to Mr Russell to go by the Ambassador’s Courier on Monday— Walked before dinner, and dined in the City with Count Bussche, the Westphalian Minister— There was a Company of about twenty-five persons— The Ambassador, Count St. Julien and most of the other foreign Ministers— In the Evening I paid a visit, to Mr and Mrs Lesseps— The Consul was very busy, preparing dispatches to go by the Ambassador’s Courier— He told me he had dined a few days since in a Company where there were a great number of Americans, and said he was convinced there were a great number of real Americans from the United States here, though there were people enough here, ready to say they were all English— I entered into details of Conversation with him to convince him that almost all the American vessels that came here loaded were Bona-Fide from America, and with Cargoes of American property; he said he gave full credit to my Statement, and should report accordingly to his Government— He shewed me his account of the vessels arrived at Cronstadt of which there were 88 Americans with Cargoes and 33. in Ballast—there were only 11. with Cargoes, under other Colours, all of which he told me he held unquestionably for English property— Every vessel loaded at Gothenburg he considered as English property— I noticed the State of the Exchange between this Country and England, and the fact that no Insurance could be obtained in England upon goods shiped for this Country, as proof that very little English property was really imported here, which he allowed—this last fact he said he had not known before, and that he should not fail to avail himself of it— After I came home I passed the Evening idly

29. I continue to read an hour or two in the morning before rising from bed— This morning I finished the first volume of the Bibliothéque des Philosophes— Containing 1. A preliminary discourse, by the anonymous editor of the Book. 2. A Discourse upon Plato, by the Abbé Fleury. 3. Reflections upon Daciers Discourse upon Plato, and his Doctrine of Plato— It is anonymous and seems to be the work of a theologian alarmed at the excess of Dacier’s admiration for Plato; for fear it should encroach upon Faith— 4. A Dedication to Louis 14. by Dacier. 5. A preface to his Pythagoras and Hierocles— 6. Life of Pythagoras— 7. His Symbols and an explanation of them. 8. Life of Hierocles. 9. The golden verses of Pythagoras, in Greek with a French Translation— The golden verses are the work of Lysis a disciple of Pythagoras— Excepting them and the symbols, both of which do not take 30 pages, the whole of this volume is preliminary— I find here a good deal of what I was looking for—the ideas of the Grecian philosophers on the Supreme being and the immortality of the Soul— As Mr Harris has not sent me the list which he had promised, and I was obliged to send my packet for the Ambassador’s Courier this Evening, I was obliged to employ a great part of the day in making out the list from my own papers— I could therefore only begin a letter to George— I read Robinson’s character of Judas Iscariot, and a Sermon in the English preacher, on the difference between the characters of a good, and of a righteous man. It rained a great part of the day, but I walked on the Mall from my door to the Karpoffka.

30. Began reading this morning the second Volume of the Bibliothéque des Philosophes. It contains Dacier’s Translation of the Commentary of Hierocles upon the golden Verses, and Dacier’s reflexions upon the Commentary— This is the most irksome of all readings, a Commentary upon a text, and reflexions upon the Commentary; not printed like notes at the bottom of each page, but in a different part of the volume— I found it very tedious— I received this day the list from Mr Harris which he had promised me; but it came too late— We had Company to dinner—Count Lauriston the French Ambassador—the Chevalier de Longuerue his Aid de Camp—Messrs:
de Rayneval, St: Genest and Prevost his Secretaries, Madame de Rayneval, Mr: and Madame and Miss Lesseps, Count St: Julien the Austrian Ministers, and Messrs Lebzeltern and Sturmer, his Secretaries, the Chevalier de Bray Bavarian Minister, and Count Jenison-Walworth his Secretary, Baron Blome, Danish Minister, Baron Schladen Prussian Minister, and Count Bussche the Westphalian Minister— They all went away soon after dinner, and we had the Evening uninterrupted.

Day. Though I have generally risen earlier this month than the last I have performed less— The cause of which has been more frequently dining abroad, and having Company to dine with us at home— Either of these Circumstances deprives me nearly of a whole day, and the loss of time is now almost universally seen in a reduction of the quantity of my writing— In this month however I have commenced two new undertakings, the one indeed dependent upon the other, but the perseverance in which will require inflexible perseverance and industry, for which I again implore Heaven— The first is a course of letters to my Son George, and the second is the investigation of mythologies— The last fortnight I have observed the practice of reading two or three hours in the morning before I rise from Bed— But there is too much indolence and luxury in it— I have therefore seldom risen, untill between nine and ten—the rest of the day employed as before— Since the cold and foul weather has become common, our visitors have been less numerous— The Evenings are growing long, and the weakness of my eyes again forces upon me many hours of idleness— I have hitherto walked before and after dinner.
